Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) five-year proposal addresses middle school students? need to learn science more deeply through the improvement of inquiry science assessment. An outgrowth of the WPI-developed ?ASSISTments Systems for Math?, and REC-funded ?Modeling Across the Curriculum?, the proposal?s main goal is to develop a rigorous, technology-based system for middle school standards-aligned assessment of inquiry skills (i.e., interpreting data, formulating hypotheses and predictions, conducting experiments, collecting data, mathematizing, and communicating and defending hypotheses) in six physical science content areas (i.e., Properties of Matter; Elements, Compounds, and Mixtures; Motion of Objects; Forms of Energy; and Heat Energy). Assessments will be aligned with the Massachusetts Curricular Framework and the National Science Education Standards.

The innovative aspect of this proposed effort resides in its intent to both assess students? inquiry skills and to provide students with intelligent, systematic (as opposed to guessing), and explicit tutoring, providing feedback on their choices as they work with computer-based manipulative models (microworlds), thus increasing their science learning. Participants include students and teachers from the Worcester Public School System, characterized by its diverse ethnic and SES student population.

Five research questions drive this research: (1) Does inquiry tutoring lead to improved inquiry skills?, (2) Does inquiry tutoring lead to increased content learning as measured by the State?s assessment system?, (3) What is the relationship of students? epistemologies of models and their inquiry with models?, (4) Do inquiry skills transfer across the six science topics as measured by better inquiry skills in each of the six skills?, and (5) What is the relationship between inquiry as measured by students? logs, and content learning as measured by pre- and post-tests on content?

Anticipated products include (a) an intelligent tutoring system capable of assessing students? skills, and providing teachers with data by class and students by inquiry skill, and (b) a set of assessment items in six physical science areas. Evaluation will emphasize the overall development of the inquiry assessments and tutoring system in relation to content learning through multiple statistical methods. Dissemination includes conferences, publications in scholarly journals, and a website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Inquiry is important in order to more deeply understand scientific principles as well as understand how science is conducted. Understanding science is important to scientific literacy as well as important to decision-making in real-life, e.g., whether or to have genetic testing, have your house tested to radon, etc. Inquiry skills are not generally developed naturally and thus, many students lack these important skills. Also, these skills are not often tested in the school system due to the amount of time and effort that it takes to assess inquiry instead, what is assessed is basic “facts” and definitions, which do not reflect the complexity of what is means to understand science.

The long-term goal of this project was to improve inquiry skills in middle school, so that students can transfer their knowledge to other science topics. Research suggests that these skills should be developed during middle school. The extent to which inquiry skills can be learned and then transferred to learn new domains was addressed as part of this project.

In order to carry out this project, we designed and developed:

• a series of microworlds (12) or virtual labs, aligned to the Massachusetts Curricular Frameworks and students’ misconceptions in Physical Science (Chemistry & Physics), (see figure 2 attached)

• a technological infrastructure, called Inq-ITS (Inquiry Intelligent Tutoring System,http://slinq.org) for collecting fine-grained log data as students engaged in inquiry with these microworlds

• a set of assessment methods, based on educational data mining and knowledge engineering, which generate real time reports on students’ inquiry skills (see figure 1 attached)

• some scaffolds (tutoring hints) to help students conduct inquiry in real time (see figure 2 attached)

We implemented these materials in many middle schools in Central Massachusetts, and tested how effective the scaffolds were at fostering the transfer of inquiry skills. In one recent study, 148 eighth grade students from a public middle school in Central Massachusetts first engaged in inquiry using our State Change microworld and then engaged in inquiry in our Density microworld. Our data showed that our data-mined assessment model for the testing stated hypotheses can correctly distinguish when a student tests their articulated hypotheses from a student who does not 91% of the time. Similarly for designing controlled experiments, our data mined assessment metric can distinguish controlled vs. confounded data collection 94% of the time. Furthermore, this model can assess whether students are conducting controlled experiments even when they do not conduct their trials sequentially, an advance over other assessments of this skill that only count sequential trials as evidence of this skill. Lastly, the model for assessing “designing controlled trials” can accurately determine which students need scaffolding on this skill in as few as three trials. We also showed that our assessment method, developed for State Change, could be validly applied to Density. This latter is important as it shows that the data mined model can be reused without further training of the machine learned models, and that it may be applicable to other topics of Physical science.

Intellectual Merit. The proposed work is potentially transformative in terms of the methods used: the development of automated metrics using knowledge engineering and educational data mining are new technique for assessing inquiry skills. This advances the state of the art in assessment for science learning. Our approach facilitates scaling up of our assessments and scaffolds, being addressed in new project currently.
